results.title: Aboriginal legends. No. 2
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia
results.brief_description: Three Aboriginal legends gathered from Tribal elders by student teachers from Kormilda College, Darwin are retold with accompanying illustrations by the students. The titles include: “The Anteater and the Turtle” - story by Nathanael Maralngura, artist Neville Jabangadi Poulson; “The old Dingo who had six wives” - story by Bill Middikari Jambidjimba, artist Harry Djagamara Nelson; “How the Kangaroo got his tail” - Story by Andrew Leku, artist Ralph Gumudul. These stories and pictures can be found in the book entitled “Djugurba”. Narrated by Juliana Allan, Wynne Nelson and Peter Gwynne.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia

results.title: Aboriginal legends. No. 1
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia
results.brief_description: Three Aboriginal legends gathered from tribal elders by student teachers from Kormilda College, Darwin are retold with accompanying illustrations by the students. The titles include: “The thirsty Sandfrog” - story by Miriam Rose Wilson, artist Ralph Gumudul; “The Witchdoctor and the two giants” - story by Lionel Jabanangga James, artist David Gentian; “Why the Kangaroo hops” - story by Nugget Jabangadi James, artist Neville Jabangadi Poulson. These stories and pictures can be found in the book entitled “Djugurba. Narrated by Juliana Allan, Wynne Nelson and Peter Gwynne.

results.title: Aboriginal fibre crafts of Aurukun
results.brief_description: The traditional fibre crafts of the Aboriginal women of Aurukun are demonstrated by Annie Kalkeeyorta and Neeyum Yunkaporta, from the collection and spinning of the fibres through to the varieties of finished products. Narrated by Jane Harders.
results.description: The traditional fibre crafts of the Aboriginal women of Aurukun are demonstrated by Annie Kalkeeyorta and Neeyum Yunkaporta, from the collection and spinning of the fibres through to the varieties of finished products. Narrated by Jane Harders.

results.title: Aboriginal Family Education Centre: Alexandria 1972
results.brief_description: A record of the Van Leewin project’s Aboriginal Family Education Centre in Redfern, Sydney. Parents learn with their children, mothers record the children’s activities with video. Differences between black and white cultural values are articulated and clarified.

results.title: Aboriginal dreaming stories (A)
results.brief_description: Jointly presented by Francis Firebrace Jones and Paulin Mcleod, these stories are presented with great enthusiasm and in the spirit of enhancing respect for the land and the Aboriginal people of Australia. The story titles are: In the beginning ; Creation of day and night ; Who discovered Australia? ; How fire came to Earth ; Giant Goanna and the Little black snake ; Why does the kookaburra laugh ; Old bush turkey ; Sharing time ; How the kangaroo got its pouch ; The Platypus ; Death of a cockatoo ; Walkabout ; The Bunyip ; “the Wallagara Man.

results.title: Aboriginal dance: cultural reflections (A)
results.brief_description: The environment has played an important role in Aboriginal society for thousands of years. The You Yangs (a big mountain in the middle of a plane) are a granite outcrop near Geelong that in the past has provided a food and water supply for the Wathaurong people. Art, music and dance provide an important outlet for the expression of culture, illustrated in this short documentary through the painting “Hunting and ceremonial grounds in the You Yangs” by Stan Couzens and in the performance of the Je Be Weng Dancers (Alan Browning, Casey Browning, Gordon Hollander, Christal Raymond). The Dancers perform 3 pieces - The Creation Dance, The Warrior Dance and The Celebration Dance. The significance of their body decoration and the movements depicted are also explained.

results.title: Aboriginal culture
results.creator_credit: Norma Disher, Keith Gow, Jerome Levy and Link Films
results.brief_description: The legends of Wayamba the turtle and Bohra the kangaroo retold by animated sketches based on the motifs of aboriginal bark paintings. An introductory sequence shows something of the variety and skill in aboriginal decorative art. Narrated by Leonard Teale.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Norma Disher, Keith Gow, Jerome Levy and Link Films

results.title: Aboriginal bark painting (A)
results.creator_credit: Latrobe University. School of Education. Media Centre
results.brief_description: Made in partnership with the Barinaga Aboriginal Co-operative at Maningrida, Northern Territory. Provides an informative look at the bark paintings of Arnhem Land, placing the art work firmly in the context of Aboriginal belief systems and using traditional techniques. A useful complement to “The art and craft of Maningrida”. Narrated by Robin Cuming.

results.title: Abnormal behavior: a mental hospital (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Tom Lazarus, Neil Reichline and CRM Productions
results.brief_description: A series of doctor-patient interviews acquaint the viewer with the symptomatology of various types of schizophrenic disturbances. In an unusual sequence, a patient with paranoid tendencies is shown undergoing electro-convulsive therapy. The director of the hospital tells of the hospital’s goals in this and other forms of treatment.
